title: 1.1: Evaluate CSS approaches (Tailwind vs CSS Modules)
description: Research and decide between Tailwind CSS, CSS Modules, or other approaches. Document pros/cons, migration effort, and team preference. Create ADR (Architecture Decision Record).
notes:
## Decision: Tailwind CSS âœ…

**Decision Date:** 2026-02-14

**Chosen Approach:** Tailwind CSS

**Reasoning:**
1. Solves core problems (scoping, naming, maintainability)
2. Massive productivity gains (2-3x faster styling)
3. Tiny bundle size (only ships used CSS)
4. Perfect for React + TypeScript + Electron
5. Industry standard with huge community
6. Future-proof and well-maintained

**Trade-offs Accepted:**
- Learning curve (2-3 weeks to get comfortable)
- Longer initial migration (3-4 weeks vs 2-3 for CSS Modules)
- Different paradigm (utility-first vs component classes)

**Why Not CSS Modules:**
- Still requires writing CSS files
- Less productive long-term
- No built-in design system

**Next Steps:**
- Create implementation tickets
- Start with setup and configuration
- Migrate incrementally, keeping tests passing

title: Epic 4: Performance Optimization
description: Profile and optimize Three.js rendering, component re-renders, and bundle size. Improve overall application performance.
notes:
## Epic 4 Plan (2026-02-15)

### Performance Landscape Assessment

**Current Status:** The app has solid fundamentals but significant optimization opportunities.

| Aspect | Status | Notes |
|--------|--------|-------|
| Render Efficiency | MODERATE | Part.tsx memoized, but sub-components and Workspace not |
| Geometry Management | POOR | No reuse/instancing, new geometry per render |
| Draw Calls | POOR | Multiple draw calls per part, no batching |
| Memory Allocation | MODERATE | Heavy Vector3 creation in hot paths |
| State Organization | POOR | God object store, large undo snapshots |
| Bundle Size | MODERATE | ~4.5-5MB, reasonable for Three.js app |
| Selector Patterns | GOOD | Fine-grained selectors with useShallow |

### Ticket Breakdown (10 tickets)

**Phase 1 - Measure (do first):**
- 4.1: Profile & establish performance baselines (P1, 1-2 days)

**Phase 2 - Quick Wins (low risk, immediate impact):**
- 4.2: Memoize sub-components and event handlers (P1, 3-5 days)
- 4.4: Reduce object allocations in hot paths (P1, 3-5 days)
- 4.5: Add debouncing/throttling (P2, 2-3 days)

**Phase 3 - Medium Impact (moderate complexity):**
- 4.3: Optimize geometry and material reuse (P1, 1 week)
- 4.7: Optimize undo/redo snapshots (P1, 3-5 days)
- 4.6: Code splitting and lazy loading (P2, 3-5 days)

**Phase 4 - Advanced (higher complexity):**
- 4.8: Frustum culling and scene optimization (P2, 1-2 weeks)
- 4.9: Bundle size analysis and optimization (P3, 3-5 days)

**Phase 5 - Close Out:**
- 4.10: Post-optimization benchmarking and documentation (P3, 1-2 days)

### Recommended Execution Order
1. Start with 4.1 (profiling) - establishes baselines for measuring improvement
2. Then 4.2 + 4.4 in parallel (quick wins, immediate measurable impact)
3. Then 4.3 + 4.7 (higher impact but more complex)
4. Then 4.5 + 4.6 (polish and startup improvement)
5. Then 4.8 if large scene perf still needs improvement
6. 4.9 for bundle optimization
7. Finish with 4.10 (benchmark and document everything)

### Dependencies / Overlaps with Other Epics
- Epic 3 (State Split) overlaps with 4.7 (undo/redo). If Epic 3 is done first, 4.7 becomes simpler.
- Epic 2 (Component Refactoring) is orthogonal - can proceed independently.
- Epic 1 (Tailwind) doesn't affect performance work.

### Total Estimated Effort: ~5-7 weeks

title: 4.1: Profile & establish performance baselines

Profile the application and establish baseline metrics before optimization work begins. This is the FIRST ticket to complete - all other Epic 4 work depends on these measurements.

**Profiling Tasks:**
1. Measure FPS during drag operations with 10, 50, 100+ parts

4. Measure memory heap size (baseline, after creating 100 parts, after undo/redo)

**Metrics to Capture (Before Optimization):**
- FPS during idle (target: 60fps)
- FPS during drag with 50 parts
- FPS during drag with 100+ parts
- Component re-render count per drag frame
- Memory heap after 100 parts

- Bundle size breakdown
- Time to first paint

**Tools:**
- Chrome DevTools Performance tab

**Deliverables:**

- Identified bottlenecks ranked by impact
- Specific recommendations for each bottleneck
- Before screenshots/recordings

**Acceptance Criteria:**

title: 4.2: Memoize sub-components and event handlers
description:
Wrap frequently-rendered sub-components in React.memo and add useCallback to event handlers to reduce unnecessary re-renders.

**Components to Memoize:**
1. ResizeHandle (rendered 12x per part - 6 faces x 2 handles)
2. RotationHandle (rendered per selected part)
3. DimensionLabel (rendered 3x per selected part)
4. SnapAlignmentLines (rendered per active snap)
5. ReferenceDistanceIndicator (rendered per reference)
6. MultiSelectionDimensions (re-calculates AABB per render)
7. Ground/Sky plane sub-components in Workspace

**Event Handlers to useCallback:**
- Part.tsx: onPointerDown, onPointerUp, onPointerMove, onPointerOver, onPointerOut
- ResizeHandle: onPointerDown, onPointerMove
- RotationHandle: onPointerDown, onPointerMove
- Workspace.tsx: onClick, onPointerMissed

**Process:**
1. Profile re-render count for each sub-component (baseline)
2. Add React.memo to each sub-component
3. Convert inline handlers to useCallback
4. Profile again and measure improvement
5. Document before/after metrics

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- All listed sub-components memoized
- Event handlers wrapped in useCallback
- Measurable reduction in re-renders during drag operations
- All tests passing
- No visual regressions

Effort: 3-5 days
Risk: LOW

title: 4.3: Optimize geometry and material reuse
description:
Reduce GPU overhead by reusing Three.js geometry and material objects instead of recreating them on every render.

**Current Problems:**
- Each Part renders `<boxGeometry args={dims} />` which creates a NEW geometry instance every render
- PlaneGeometry created fresh for ground/sky meshes on every Workspace render
- Materials created inline with conditional logic, recreated each render
- 12 resize handles per part each create their own box geometry
- No geometry sharing between parts of the same dimensions

**Optimization Plan:**

1. **Geometry Caching/Pooling:**
   - Create a geometry cache keyed by dimensions (width, height, depth)
   - Parts with identical dimensions share geometry instances
   - Use `useMemo` to cache geometries by dimension tuple
   - Dispose unused geometries when parts are removed

2. **Material Optimization:**
   - Create materials once and reuse via `useMemo`
   - Use material.clone() only when per-instance properties differ (color)
   - Share materials for identical display modes
   - Pre-create materials for common display modes (solid, wireframe, transparent)

3. **Handle Geometry Sharing:**
   - All resize handles use the same small box geometry - share ONE instance
   - Rotation handles share geometry
   - Selection indicators share geometry

4. **Ground/Sky Optimization:**
   - Create ground plane geometry once (never changes)
   - Create sky sphere geometry once
   - Cache via useRef or module-level constants

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Geometry instances reduced by 80%+ (measure with renderer.info)
- Material instances reduced by 50%+
- No visual regressions
- Draw call count reduced
- All tests passing

Effort: 1 week
Risk: MEDIUM - need to ensure proper disposal to avoid memory leaks

title: 4.4: Reduce object allocations in hot render paths
description:
Eliminate unnecessary object creation in frequently-executed code paths (useFrame callbacks, drag handlers, bounding box calculations).

**Current Problems:**

1. **Bounding Box Calculations (8 Vector3 per call):**
   - Workspace.tsx camera centering: creates 8 new Vector3 per part per camera center
   - Part.tsx AABB calculation: 8 Vector3 objects created per call
   - MultiSelectionDimensions: rebuilds bounds array on every dependency change

2. **Per-Frame Allocations in useFrame:**
   - Camera controller creates Euler, Quaternion, Vector3 during drag
   - Snap detection creates temporary bounds objects per frame
   - Vector3 math creates intermediate results

3. **Array Recreation:**
   - allPartIds set recreated on every selection change in CameraController
   - SnapAlignmentLines maps over array creating new group objects each render
   - Temporary arrays in filter/map chains

**Optimization Plan:**

1. **Object Pooling for Vector3/Matrix4:**
   - Create module-level or useRef pools of reusable Vector3/Euler/Quaternion
   - Pattern: `const _tempVec = new THREE.Vector3()` at module level
   - Reset and reuse instead of creating new

2. **Memoize Expensive Calculations:**
   - Cache bounding box results with useMemo keyed on part positions/dimensions
   - Only recalculate when parts actually change
   - Use shallow comparison for arrays

3. **Reduce Array Allocations:**
   - Use for-loops instead of map/filter chains in hot paths
   - Pre-allocate arrays where size is known
   - Cache derived collections (allPartIds)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Zero new Vector3/Euler/Quaternion allocations in useFrame callbacks
- Bounding box calculations use pooled objects
- GC pressure measurably reduced (fewer minor GC events in DevTools)
- All tests passing
- No visual regressions

Effort: 3-5 days
Risk: LOW - internal optimization, no API changes
close_reason: Implemented in PR #180. Replaced per-frame THREE.js object allocations with pre-allocated reusable objects across all hot render paths. Created shared mathPool.ts utility. ~91-100% GC pressure reduction.

title: 4.5: Add debouncing and throttling to expensive operations
description:
Add rate-limiting to operations that fire too frequently, causing unnecessary computation.

**Operations to Debounce/Throttle:**

1. **Snap Line Calculations (Throttle: 16ms / 60fps):**
   - Snap detection runs on every pointer move during drag
   - Involves distance calculations to all other parts
   - Throttle to animation frame rate

2. **Reference Distance Calculations (Throttle: 16ms):**
   - Reference distance indicators update on every move
   - Complex math per reference part
   - Throttle to match frame rate

3. **Dimension Label Updates (Debounce: 32ms):**
   - Text labels update on every position change
   - Involves text measurement and positioning
   - Slight debounce acceptable for labels

4. **Selection Box Calculations (Throttle: 16ms):**
   - Selection box drag fires many events
   - Intersection tests against all parts
   - Throttle to animation frame rate

5. **Store Updates During Drag (Batch):**
   - Multiple store updates per drag frame (position, snap lines, references)
   - Batch into single state update using Zustand set()

**Implementation:**
- Use requestAnimationFrame for throttling (natural 60fps cap)
- Use lodash/throttle or custom RAF-based throttle
- Debounce with leading edge for immediate feedback
- Batch related store updates into single set() calls

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Snap calculations throttled to frame rate
- Reference distances throttled to frame rate
- Store updates batched during drag operations
- Smoother drag experience with complex scenes
- All tests passing

Effort: 2-3 days
Risk: LOW

   - Target: 50-70% reduction in snapshot memory

3. **Optimize Equality Checking:**

   - Reduce unnecessary snapshot creation during drag operations

4. **Limit History Size:**

title: 4.8: Implement frustum culling and scene optimization for large projects
description:
Optimize rendering for projects with many parts (50-200+) by implementing frustum culling, draw call reduction, and scene graph optimization.

**Current Problem:**
- Every part renders ALL sub-components regardless of visibility
- No frustum culling - parts behind camera still process render logic
- Each part generates multiple draw calls (box + edges + handles + labels)
- With 100+ parts, frame rate drops significantly

**Optimization Plan:**

1. **Frustum Culling:**
   - React Three Fiber handles basic frustum culling for mesh objects by default
   - Verify it is working correctly (check frustumCulled property)
   - Ensure bounding spheres/boxes are set correctly for culling
   - Parts outside camera frustum should skip complex rendering

2. **Conditional Detail Rendering:**
   - Only render resize/rotation handles for selected parts (may already be done)
   - Only render dimension labels for selected parts
   - Only render edge lines for parts within a distance threshold
   - Skip grain direction arrows for distant parts

3. **Draw Call Batching:**
   - Merge edge geometries for non-selected parts into a single BufferGeometry
   - Use InstancedMesh for resize handles (all identical geometry)
   - Batch grid lines into single geometry

4. **Scene Graph Optimization:**
   - Minimize group nesting in Three.js scene
   - Avoid unnecessary matrix recalculations
   - Use object.matrixAutoUpdate = false for static parts

**Performance Targets:**
- 60fps with 100 parts during idle
- 30fps+ with 100 parts during drag
- 60fps with 200 parts during idle

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Measurable FPS improvement with 100+ parts
- Frustum culling verified working
- Draw calls reduced for large scenes
- No visual regressions
- All tests passing

Effort: 1-2 weeks
Risk: MEDIUM - complex Three.js optimization
